questions.text:
A 60-year-old patient who is a known case of diabetes mellitus with an HbA1c value of 8.8% has been posted for surgery after pre-anesthetic evaluation. Which of the following is used for the physical status classification of the patient during the pre-anesthetic evaluation?

American Society of Anesthesiologists - ASA
questions.solution:
The American Society of Anesthesiologists classification (ASA-PS) is used to classify physical status.

An integral part of the pre-anesthetic evaluation is assessing a patient's risk for undergoing anesthesia and surgery. This helps the anesthetist make informed clinical decisions and helps the patient understand their risks. 

After classifying patients based on this risk assessment, those who require more intensive postoperative monitoring can be identified. In addition, patients who are at high risk for complications can be identified and alternative interventions considered. 

The ASA-PS is the most commonly used risk assessment. However, it is important to note that it describes only the patient's preoperative status and not the risks associated with the specific procedure that the patient will undergo. 

Thyromental distance (Option A), Mallampati classification (Option B), and neck circumference (Option D) are used to assess difficult airways. 

 

Related Pearl: American Society of Anesthesiologists’ Physical Status Classification of Patients

American Society of Anesthesiologists Physical Status (ASA-PS) classification is used to define relative risk before conscious sedation and surgical anaesthesia and strongly correlates to perioperative risk.

ASA-PS Classification:

Class Definition Examples, including, but not limited to:
I A normal healthy patient Healthy, non-smoking, no or minimal alcohol use
II A patient with mild systemic disease Current smoker, well-controlled DM and HTN
III A patient with severe systemic disease Poorly controlled DM or HTN, history (>3 months) of MI, CVA, TIA, or CAD or stents.
IV A patient with severe systemic disease that is a constant threat to life Recent (< 3 months) MI, CVA, TIA, or CAD/stents
V A moribund patient who is not expected to survive without the operation Ruptured abdominal, thoracic aneurysm, massive trauma, intracranial bleed with mass effect
VI A declared brain-dead patient whose organs are being removed for donor purposes  

Related Pearl: Predictors of Difficult Airway

Risk factors:

  1. Obstructive sleep apnea
  2. History of snoring
  3. Obesity
  4. Facial and neck deformities from previous surgery
  5. Previous head and neck radiation
  6. Head and neck trauma
  7. Congenital abnormalities of the head and neck
  8. Rheumatoid arthritis
  9. Down syndrome
  10. Scleroderma
  11. Cervical spine disease or previous cervical spine surgery

Specific tests for assessment:

  1. Mallampati scores (III and IV)
  2. Thyromental distance less than 6 cm
  3. Sterno-mental distance <12.5 cm with head in maximum extension
  4. Increased neck circumference >17 inches in men or >16 inches in women
  5. Upper lip bite test: Inability to protrude the mandible or lower teeth in front of the upper teeth
  6. Cormack and Lehane (laryngoscopic view) - Grade III and IV

Although the presence of these risk factors may not be sensitive in detecting difficult intubation, the absence of these findings indicates ease with intubation.

Related Pearl: Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification

Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification is used to predict the ease of endotracheal intubation.

• Class I: The entire palatal arch, including the bilateral faucial pillars, is visible down to the bases of the pillars.
• Class II: The upper part of the faucial pillars and most of the uvula are visible.
• Class III: Only the soft and hard palates are visible.
• Class IV: Only the hard palate is visible.

Initially, the Mallampatti scoring system (1985) had only 3 classes. This was modified by Samsoon and Young to include class 4. Later class 0 was also added.

questions.text: An anatomy resident while observing the histological section of the thymus under high magnification identifies the following structure in the medullary area of the thymus. These structures are derived from which pharyngeal pouch?
questions.solution:
The magnified view of the histology slide shows the Hassall’s corpuscles (thymic corpuscles) which are seen in the medullary area of the thymus. They are derived from the 3rd pharyngeal pouch.

Hassall’s corpuscles are small rounded structures formed from whorls of medullary epithelial cells with a central partially keratinized core appearing as eosinophilic staining mass.

The 3rd pharyngeal pouch gives rise to the thymus in the ventral part and the inferior parathyroid gland in the dorsal part. The thymus then moves away from the pharyngeal wall in a caudal and medial direction, pulling the inferior parathyroid with it. It reaches the anterior part of the thorax, where it fuses with its counterpart from the opposite side.

The endodermal cells of the thymus get invaded by the vascular mesoderm, which contains numerous lymphoblasts. Hassall’s corpuscles (thymic corpuscles) are derived from the endoderm of the 3rd pouch.

The following image describes the derivatives of the pharyngeal pouches.

 

Other options:

Option A - First pharyngeal pouch gives rise to the middle ear cavity and eustachian tube.

Option B - Second pharyngeal pouch gives rise to the palatine tonsils and tonsillar fossa.

Option D - Fourth pharyngeal pouch gives rise to the superior parathyroid gland, ultimobranchial body which then develop into the parafollicular "C" cells of the thyroid gland.

questions.text: After a diet rich in cholesterol, it is seen that the de novo synthesis of cholesterol in the liver decreases. Which of the following enzymes is involved in this?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the enzyme HMG CoA reductase is involved in the regulation of cholesterol synthesis in the body.

HMG-CoA is reduced to mevalonate by NADPH in a reaction catalyzed by HMG-CoA reductase which is the principal regulatory step in the pathway of cholesterol synthesis. It is the site of action of the cholesterol-lowering statins, which are HMG-CoA reductase inhibitors.

Long-term regulation of cholesterol synthesis involves regulating the transcription of the gene for HMG CoA reductase. When there is sufficient cholesterol in the cell, transcription of the gene for HMG CoA reductase is suppressed, and there is decreased synthesis of cholesterol. 

When cholesterol is less, proteases in the Golgi bodies cleave a sterol regulatory element-binding protein (SREBP). The protein which is then formed binds to a sterol regulatory element (SRE) on the DNA. This activates transcription of the HMG CoA reductase gene which increases cholesterol synthesis.

Hormones that influence HMG reductase are:

  • Insulin and thyroxine increase the activity of HMG CoA reductase
  • Cortisol and glucagon decrease the activity of HMG CoA reductase
  • Statins inhibit the activity of HMG CoA reductase

Other options:

Option A: Acetoacetyl CoA synthase catalyzes the reaction that combines two molecules of acetyl-CoA condense forming acetoacetyl-CoA. This acetoacetyl-CoA enters the cholesterol synthesis pathway along with a molecule of acetyl-CoA.

Option B: HMG CoA lyase is involved in ketone body synthesis which converts HMG coA to acetoacetate. 

Option C: HMG CoA synthase catalyzes the reaction where the third molecule of acetyl CoA condenses with acetoacetyl CoA forming beta-hydroxy beta-methyl glutaryl CoA (HMG CoA).

questions.text: The data which best explains the difference between the highest and the lowest values is:
questions.solution:
Range gives the difference between the highest and lowest values in a given set of data.

In a dataset of marks of students in a subject, if the highest score is 100 and the lowest is 51, the range would be 49.

Option A: Variance (var or SD²) is the mean of the squares of all the deviation scores of the distribution. It is used to measure how far data is spread out.

Option B: Coefficient of variation (CV) is used to compare the variability. For example, whether the pulse varies more in old or young and growth varies more in boys or girls. It is calculated by expressing SD as a percentage of the mean, i.e., CV = SD/mean x 100. Since it is expressed as a percentage it doesn't have any units.

Option D: Quartiles divide the distribution into 4 equal groups. The difference between mid values of each quartile gives the interquartile range.

Related Pearl: Measures in Statistics

Measures used in statistics

Definition

Examples

Measures of Location or Central Tendency

These measures summarize the data by defining the centre or the middle.

An entire distribution can be characterized by these measures which represent all the observations.

Mean, median, mode

Measures of Dispersion or Variability or Spread

These measures help in determining the extent to which data is stretched or squeezed.

Range, interquartile range, variance, standard deviation

Measures of Position

These measures give the position of specific data in relation to other data in the set.

Percentiles, quartiles, centiles,  z scores

 

Related Pearl: The Range in Biostatistics

  • The range is the simplest measure of variability or dispersion. It is the difference between the highest and lowest scores in the data distribution.
  • The main advantage of the range is that it is easy to compute.
  • The disadvantage of the range is that it is sensitive to extreme values.
  • Examples: For a set of values: 9, 15, 25, 30, 40 – the range = 40 – 9 = 31. But for a set of values: 9, 20, 30, 40, 500 – the range = 500 – 9 = 491.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presented with the following lesions. Her serum angiotensin-converting enzyme levels were found to be higher than normal. What is the likely systemic disease associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
This patient with cutaneous red-purple indurated plaques and nodules over the nose and cheeks and elevated angiotensin-converting enzyme levels is likely to have lupus pernio. The likely systemic disease associated with this condition is sarcoidosis. 

Cutaneous sarcoidosis presents as red‐brown or red violaceous nodules or plaques, generally multiple, and does not cause symptoms. Diascopy reveals the subtle brown‐yellow or ‘apple jelly’ color characteristic of granulomatous diseases but is usually more opaque than in lupus vulgaris. At diagnosis, at least 60% of patients have an increased serum angiotensin‐converting enzyme level.

Lupus pernio is the most distinctive manifestation of cutaneous sarcoidosis. It presents as infiltrated erythemato-violaceous plaques involving the nose, cheeks, ears, lips, forehead, and fingers. On the cheeks, a prominent telangiectatic component is characteristic. The clinical appearance is due to the presence of epithelioid cell granulomas in the dermis.

Lupus pernio is usually painless and, as it does not tend to ulcerate, is not as mutilating as lupus vulgaris. In more than half of cases, it is associated with sarcoidosis of the upper respiratory tract, especially in patients with involvement of the nasal rims. It is also frequently associated with pulmonary fibrosis, chronic uveitis, and bony cysts, particularly affecting the terminal phalanges.

The image below shows the apple jelly appearance on diascopy:

Other options:
Option A: Heliotrope rash presents as violaceous lesions around eyelids. It is seen in dermatomyositis.

Option B: Lupus vulgaris is a manifestation of cutaneous tuberculosis. The lesions are usually plaques with soft, reddish-brown papules. The lesions gradually become elevated, infiltrated, and grow by slow peripheral extension to become gyrate or discoid in shape with areas of atrophy. The following image depicts the lesions of lupus vulgaris.

Option C: Erysipelas presents as erythematous raised lesions with sharply demarcated edges. It is caused due to streptococcal skin infection.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presented with a speech disorder and a history of recurrent bouts of secretory otitis media in the past. On examination, he was found to have a bifid uvula and a short soft palate with adenoid hypertrophy. The patient underwent adenoidectomy. The most specific speech disorder expected in this patient postoperatively is:

choices.text: Rhinolalia clausa due to postoperative nasopharyngeal stenosis
Rhinolalia aperta due to postoperative velopharyngeal insufficiency
Rhinolalia clausa due to postoperative velopharyngeal insufficiency
Rhinolalia aperta due to postoperative nasopharyngeal stenosis

questions.solution:
Rhinolalia aperta due to postoperative velopharyngeal insufficiency is the most specific postoperative complication in this case.

Preoperatively, the patient initially presents with a speech disorder, most probably, rhinolalia clausa (hypo-nasality) due to adenoid hypertrophy. Rhinilalia clausa is the lack of nasal resonance for words that are normally resonated in the nasal cavity such as m, n, and ng. It occurs due to blockage of the nose or nasopharynx. 

Postoperatively, the patient with a history of bifid uvula and short soft palate (significant of submucous cleft palate) is likely to develop rhinolalia aperta (hypernasality). In this condition, words that have little resonance, are resonated in the nose. This occurs because the nasopharynx cannot be cut off from the oropharynx or when there is abnormal communication between the oral and nasal cavities. The presence of a submucous cleft palate is a contraindication for adenoidectomy as it can lead to velopharyngeal insufficiency.

 

Rhinolalia clausa
(Hyponasality)		 Rhinolalia aperta
(Hypernasality)
Common cold Velopharyngeal insufficiency
Nasal allergy Congenitally short soft palate
Nasal polypi Submucous palate
Nasal growth Large nasopharynx
Adenoids Cleft of the soft palate
Nasopharyngeal mass Paralysis of the soft palate
Familial speech pattern Post adenoidectomy
Habitual Oronasal fistula
  Familial speech pattern
  Habitual

questions.text: Under McNaughten's rule, which of the following criteria is not valid to clear a mentally unsound person of all responsibility?

choices.text: Psychiatric illness while committing the crime
Inability to understand that the act is wrong

questions.solution:
The criterion of the presence of uncontrollable impulse is not included in McNaughten's rule. Therefore, it is not a valid criterion to clear a mentally unsound person of all criminal responsibility.

McNaughten's rule is followed by the British Courts of law to examine the liability of a mentally unsound person who has committed a crime. BNS 22 is the Indian adaptation of this rule. 

McNaughten's rule forms the basis of the legal test of insanity/the 'right or wrong' test. It states that a mentally unsound person is cleared of all criminal responsibility for the crime committed if the following criteria are met:

  • Presence of evidence of psychiatric illness.
  • Existence of psychiatric illness at the time of the commission of the crime.
  • Psychiatric illness is of such a degree that the person does not have the ability to understand the wrongness of the act, i.e., impaired intellectual ability. 

McNaughten's rule decide a person's soundness of mind based on the presence or absence of intellectual ability. However, it fails to consider any impairments in the person's emotional state or the presence of any uncontrollable/ irresistible impulses while committing the act. 

Related Pearl: Criminal Responsibilities

BNS section

Previous IPC Section

Deals with

 18

-

Not liable

If done by accident or misfortune and without any criminal intention or knowledge in the doing of a lawful act in a lawful manner by lawful means and with proper care and caution.

 20

82

A child under 7 years is not liable for the act.

21

83

Child of 7–12 years if not attained proper mental maturity is not liable for the act.

22

84  

McNaughten's rule: A person of unsound mind is not liable for the act.

23

85

A person who under involuntary intoxication has commited an act is not liable for the act.

24

86

A person who under voluntary intoxication commits an act is liable for the act.

questions.text: A young non-obese patient presented with increased fatigue for several months. Two of his relatives have a history of early-onset diabetes. Investigations revealed high blood glucose and low serum insulin levels. Urine ketones and islet autoantibodies were negative.  There was an improvement after 2 weeks of glimepiride. Which of the following is incorrect regarding this condition?

choices.text: It responds to all oral hypoglycemic agents
It is associated with cystic kidney disease

questions.solution:
This patient is likely to have maturity-onset diabetes of the young (MODY). It responds only to sulphonylureas (glimepiride, glipizide), not all oral hypoglycemic agents.

The clinical vignette describes a young non-obese patient with a positive family history of diabetes. Features of reduced insulin level with no antibodies, negative urinary ketones, and a good response to a sulphonylurea drug (glimepiride) rule out the possibility of Type 1 diabetes mellitus.

MODY is a monogenic disorder inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion. It is generally inherited at the age of 25 years or younger. Patients are generally not obese. The pathophysiology of this condition involves impaired glucose-induced secretion of insulin. 

There are six types of MODY. However, type 3 is the most common. Types 1, 3 and 5 occur due to mutations in the hepatic nuclear factor. Type 2 occurs due to a mutation in the glucokinase gene and type 4 occurs due to mutations in pancreatic and duodenal homeobox 1. MODY type 5 is associated with renal cysts.

Patients usually respond to therapy with sulfonylureas but eventually require insulin as a result of beta-cell failure. 

Related Pearl: Comparative Features between MODY and Type 2 DM

 

Type 2 DM

MODY

Age of onset

Predominantly middle to old age

Predominantly young (< 25 years)

Pathology

Beta cell dysfunction

Insulin resistance

Only Beta cell dysfunction

No insulin resistance

Family history

Positive

Inheritance - Polygenic 

Vertical transmission through successive generations is not essential for diagnosis

Positive

Inheritance – Monogenic / Autosomal dominant 

Vertical transmission through at least two successive generation (ideally three) is essential for diagnosis

Insulin dependence

Non-insulin dependent

Non-insulin dependent

Obesity

Common

Uncommon

DKA

Uncommon

Uncommon

Serum insulin level

High

Low

Related Pearl: Types of Diabetes mellitus

I. Type 1 diabetes: Beta cell destruction, usually leading to absolute insulin deficiency

  • Immune-mediated
  • Idiopathic

II. Type 2 diabetes: Insulin resistance with relative insulin deficiency

III. Other specific types of diabetes

  • Genetic defects of beta cell development or function
    • MODY – Maturity Onset Diabetes of Young
  • Genetic defects in insulin action
    • Type A insulin resistance
    • Leprechaunism
    • Rabson-Mendenhall syndrome Lipodystrophy syndromes
  • Diseases of the exocrine pancreas
    • Pancreatitis
    • Neoplasia
    • Cystic fibrosis
    • Hemochromatosis
  • Endocrinopathies
    • Acromegaly
    • Cushing’s syndrome
    • Glucagonoma
    • Pheochromocytoma
    • Hyperthyroidism
  • Infections
    • Congenital rubella
    • Cytomegalovirus
    • Coxsackievirus
  • Uncommon forms of immune-mediated diabetes
    • “Stiff-person” syndrome
    • Anti-insulin receptor antibodies
  • Genetic syndromes sometimes associated with diabetes
    • Wolfram’s syndrome
    • Down’s syndrome, Klinefelter’s syndrome, Turner’s syndrome

IV. Gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM)

questions.text: A 34-year-old male patient presented with severe dyspnea, mild fever, joint pains, and joint swelling. He has had similar episodes in the past. Examination revealed mitral stenosis and left atrial hypertrophy. Echocardiography showed small warty vegetations along the lines of the closure of the mitral valve leaflets. How long will you give secondary prophylaxis to this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient with repeated episodes of severe dyspnea, mild fever, arthralgia, joint swelling, mitral stenosis, and warty valvular vegetation is likely to have rheumatic heart disease. Since he is a 34-year-old with carditis with residual valve disease, he should receive prophylaxis until he is 44 years of age. 

Secondary prophylaxis is given to patients with acute rheumatic fever (ARF) and rheumatic heart disease (RHD). These patients are at a higher risk of developing a further episode after a group A streptococcal infection. Hence they should receive long-term penicillin prophylaxis to prevent recurrent infections. 

In those with rheumatic fever with persistent valvular disease, prophylaxis should be given for 10 years after the last episode or till they attain 40 years of age (whichever is longer). As he is 34 years of age, providing prophylaxis for 10 years till he attains 44 years of age is longer than until he turns 40.

Lifelong medication can be continued in severe valvular disease or postintervention (after valve surgery) patients.

The best antibiotic for secondary prophylaxis is benzathine penicillin G (1.2 million units) given every 4 weeks. Oral penicillin V (250 mg) can be given twice daily instead, but is less effective than benzathine penicillin G. Patients who are allergic to penicillin can receive erythromycin (250 mg) twice daily.

Related Pearl: American Heart Association (AHA) recommendation for duration of secondary prophylaxis of rheumatic fever

Category

Duration after the last attack

Rheumatic fever without carditis

  

5 years or until 21 years of age (whichever is longer)

Rheumatic fever with carditis but no residual heart disease (no valvular disease)

  10 years or until 21 years of age (whichever is longer)

Rheumatic fever with carditis and residual heart disease (persistent valvular disease)

10 years or until 40 years of age (whichever is longer), sometimes lifelong prophylaxis

Related Pearl: Revised Jones criteria for diagnosis of Acute Rheumatic Fever (ARF)

Revised Jones criteria for the diagnosis of rheumatic fever are as follows:

Major criteria
Low-risk populations* Moderate- and high-risk populations*
   
Carditis- Clinical or subclinical Carditis- Clinical or subclinical
Arthritis- Polyarthritis only Arthritis- Polyarthritis/polyarthralgia/monoarthritis
Chorea Chorea
Erythema marginatum Erythema marginatum
Subcutaneous nodules Subcutaneous nodules
   
Minor criteria 
Polyarthralgia Monoarthralgia
Fever (≥38.5°C) Fever (≥38°C)
ESR ≥60 mm in the first hour and/or CRP ≥3.0 mg/dL ESR ≥30 mm/hr and/or CRP ≥3.0 mg/dL
Prolonged PR interval, after accounting for age variability (unless carditis is a major criterion) Prolonged PR interval, after accounting for age variability (unless carditis is a major criterion) 
   
For all patient populations with evidence of preceding Group A Streptococcal infection:(Increased ASLO/ anti-DNAse B titer or positive throat culture for group A streptococcus or positive rapid streptococcal carbohydrate antigen test) 
Diagnosis of initial ARF 2 Major criteria or 1 major plus 2 minor criteria
Diagnosis of recurrent ARF 2 Major or 1 major and 2 minor or 3 minor criteria

*Low-risk populations are those with ARF incidence ≤2 per 100 000 school-aged children or all-age rheumatic heart disease prevalence of ≤1 per 1000 population per year. If the incidence exceeds the given limit, then it is moderate-high risk populations.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presented with psychosis and visual hallucinations that began several months ago. He now has dementia,  memory loss, impaired judgment, and intermittent myoclonus. He passes away 1 year after the onset of symptoms. Brain biopsy reveals PrPsc proteins accumulations. Which of the following is this agent sensitive to?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette suggests Creutzfeldt Jakob disease, a condition caused by prions. Prions are sensitive to phenol.

The patient with psychosis, visual hallucinations, dementia, memory loss, impaired judgment, intermittent myoclonus, death one year after onset of symptoms, and brain biopsy significant for PrPSc accumulations is likely to have Creutzfeldt Jakob disease.  

Prions are the proteinaceous infectious particle that lacks nucleic acid, composed entirely of alternatively folded proteins that undergo self-propagation. PrPSc is the disease-causing isoform of the prion protein. Diagnosis can be established by detecting PrPSc proteins in brain biopsy. However, the diagnosis can be made clinically.

Prions are resistant to formaldehyde, urea, dry heat, boiling, ethanol, proteases, deoxycholate, and ionizing radiation. They are sensitive to phenol, household bleach, ether, sodium hydroxide, strong detergents, and autoclaving. 

Other diseases caused by prions include:

  • Creutzfeldt­ Jakob disease
  • Gerstmann­ Sträussler ­Scheinke syndrome 
  • Fatal familial insomnia                       
  • Kuru in humans                          
  • Scrapie in sheep and goats   
  • Bovine spongiform en­cephalopathy in cows

questions.text: A 25-year-old overweight woman presents with complaints of irregular periods for the last year. Physical examination revealed a BMI of 32 kg/m2 with signs of hirsutism. Pelvic sonographic findings show multiple ovarian follicles arranged in a necklace pattern. Which of the following drugs cannot be used in the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of polycystic ovarian disease (PCOD). Centrochroman is not used in the treatment of PCOD. 

PCOD is attributed to obesity, smoking, and poor diet. The affected ovary or ovaries have cysts (12 or more) that are composed of atretic follicles, coupled with theca and stromal cell hyperplasia.  

Symptoms of PCOD include hirsutism and acne (due to hyperandrogenism), anovulation followed by amenorrhea, or heavy menstrual or intermenstrual bleeding.

Diagnosis is made by pelvic ultrasound which shows "necklace" appearance. Endomtrial hyperplasia may also be present. 

Treatment of PCOD includes lifestyle modification such as smoking cessation, diet, and exercise with a focus on weight reduction, combined oral contraceptives to regularize menstrual cycles and decrease androgen levels. 

To treat hirsutism, 5α-reductase inhibitors like finasteride are effective; eflornithine hydrochloride cream prevents hair growth.
 
Clomiphene is the first line of treatment for women with infertility. It may be combined with dexamethasone to improve the fertility rate.

Metformin treats the root cause of PCOS, rectifies endocrine and metabolic functions, and improves the fertility rate. It is used as an insulin sensitizer and induces spontaneous ovulation.

Surgery is indicated when medical therapy fails, when there is a history of previous pregnancy losses, when there is infertility, or when hyperstimulation occurs. Surgery comprises of laparoscopic ovarian drilling of not more than 4 cysts in each ovary by laser or unipolar electric cautery. It improves fertility for a period of one year. 

Related Pearl: Management of PCOD

Complaint Management  
Irregular periods OCPs
Obesity Lifestyle modification
Insulin resistance Metformin
Hirsutism /acne OCPs with cyproterone acetate
Infertility Clomiphene

Note: Letrozole is as effective as Clomiphene in treating infertility in PCOD with fewer side effects. However, it's pending FDA approval and is used off-label.

Related Pearl: Endocrinological changes of PCOD

  1. Elevated Estrone/E1 levels.
  2. LH level is raised over 10 IU/mL. FSH level remains normal to low, but FSH/LH ratio falls.
  3. Testosterone and epi-androstenedione levels rise.
    • Testosterone elevated but < 200 ng/dL (normal range 20 -80 ng/dL)
    • Testosterone > 200 ng/dL suggests androgen-secreting ovarian tumor
    • DHEA-S values may be normal or slightly elevated
    • DHEA >700 ng/mL suggests adrenal tumour
  4. Serum SHBG is reduced.
  5. Triglyceride level >150 mg/dL-hyperlipidaemia HDL <50 mg/dL.
  6. Fasting blood glucose/fasting insulin <4.5 suggests insulin resistance
  7. Prolactin is mildly raised in 15% cases
  8. Fasting insulin is more than 10 mIU/L in PCOS in 50–70%cases
  9. Thyroid function tests may be abnormal (hypothyroidism)
  10. 17-a-hydroxyprogesterone in the follicular phase >300 ng/dL suggests adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
  11. Urinary cortisol <50 μg/24 h.

questions.text: After a road traffic accident, an old man experienced the sudden blurring of vision and floaters in his right eye. What would be the ideal investigation of choice for the suspected vitreous hemorrhage?
questions.solution:
The investigation of choice for vitreous hemorrhage is an ultrasound B-scan.

B-scan ultrasonography in unclotted vitreous hemorrhage generally shows a uniform appearance, and once cellular aggregates develop, small particulate echoes become visible.

USG B can also be used to assess posterior segment in the case of opaque media, and study intraocular tumors, orbital tumors, and other mass lesions. 

Vitreous hemorrhage has a variable presentation depending on the severity of the hemorrhage. The mild hemorrhage causes sudden onset floaters and diffuse blurring of vision, but may not affect visual acuity, whilst a dense bleed may result in sudden painless loss of vision.

Causes

  • Acute posterior vitreous detachment associated either with a retinal tear or avulsion of a peripheral vessel
  • Proliferative retinopathy
    • Diabetic
    • Retinal vein occlusion
    • Sickle cell disease
    • Eales disease
    • Vasculitis
  • Miscellaneous retinal disorders
    • Macroaneurysm
    • Telangiectasia
    • Capillary hemangioma
  • Trauma
  • Systemic
    • Bleeding disorders
    • Terson syndrome

Treatment is dictated by severity and cause, but an increasingly low threshold is being adopted for early vitrectomy.

Terson syndrome
Terson syndrome refers to the combination of intraocular and subarachnoid hemorrhage secondary to aneurysmal rupture, most commonly arising from the anterior communicating artery.

Other options: 

Option A - Optical coherence tomography is used to provide cross-sectional or tomographic images of tissues of less than 10um axial resolution using light waves. It is used to image the anterior chamber angle, trabeculotomy blebs, tumors and cysts of the iris and ciliary body, macular disorders, diagnose glaucoma and in pachymetry. 

Option B - Ultrasound A-scan produces a unidimensional image. It is used to measure axial length, anterior chamber depth, and thickness of intraocular masses. 

Option D - Electroretinography records changes in the resting potential of the eye that are induced by flashes of light. It is used to evaluate retinal disorders, function, especially in cases where fundal examination is not possible.

questions.text:
A 5-year-old male child presents with complaints of high-grade fever, pain in the right knee joint for more than a week, and a recent episode of sore throat. Examination reveals knee joint tenderness. Laboratory evaluation showed elevated WBC count, ESR, and CRP. X-ray showed a faint extracortical outline in the proximal tibia. Which of the following is false regarding the complications associated with this condition?

WBC - White blood cell

ESR - Erythrocyte sedimentation rate

CRP - C-reactive protein

choices.text: Suppurative arthritis can occur if the metaphysis is intra-articular
Pathological fractures are not commonly seen in this condition
Epiphyseal damage is commonly seen in elderly individuals
Psuedoarthrosis can occur at the hip joint in  infants

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute hematogenous osteomyelitis and epiphyseal damage is seen in neonates and infants.

Acute osteomyelitis

Causative organisms:

  • Staphylococcus is the most common organism causing osteomyelitis.
  • Pseudomonas is the most common cause in IV drug abusers
  • Salmonella is the most common cause in patients of sickle cell anemia
  • H.influenzae was a common causative organism in children, less common now because of vaccination
  • Streptococcus
  • E.coli

Route of infection: Acute osteomyelitis can be hematogenous or from exogenous routes such as open fractures, iatrogenic intervention, or spread from local infection.

Cardinal features of acute osteomyelitis in children include:

  • Fever
  • Pain
  • Refusal to bear weight
  • Elevated WBC count
  • Elevated CRP
  • Elevated ESR

X-ray findings:

  • During the first week, the X-ray appear to be normal and by the second week, a faint extracortical line may be visible due to periosteal new bone formation. This is a classic sign of early pyogenic osteomyelitis.
  • A combination of regional osteoporosis with a localized segment of apparently increased density is an important late finding in this condition.

Management of acute osteomyelitis:

Collection of blood samples for culture and sensitivity test, followed by immediate empirical antibiotic therapy to prevent septicemia and other complications. 

Surgical drainage is indicated only in the following two circumstances

  • Presence of an abscess requiring drainage
  • Whenever the patient does not respond to antibiotics

Supportive therapy includes analgesics, IV fluids, and splinting of the limb.

The complications of inadequately treated acute osteomyelitis include: 

  • Septicemia- Nowadays this is a rare complication due to prompt antibiotic therapy.
  • Epiphyseal damage and altered bone growth- This is seen in neonates and infants as their epiphyses are entirely cartilaginous. So the metaphysical vessels can penetrate into the physis and carry the infection to the epiphysis. In some cases involving the hip joint, the femoral head is so badly damaged and can lead to pseudoarthrosis.
  • Septic arthritis- It is seen when the metaphysics is intraarticular, in very young infants as the growth plate is penetrable, and from metastatic infection
  • Pathological fracture- It is an uncommon complication, but can occur if there is a treatment delay and a weakened bone due to erosion or overzealous debridement.
  • Chronic osteomyelitis

questions.text: You observe that the arms of an infant extend spontaneously when the senior resident tries to elicit the following reflex by holding the infant’s trunk and then suddenly lowering the infant as if he or she were falling. All the following options regarding this reflex are true, except ______.

choices.text: This reflex is  a prerequisite to walking.
This reflex starts to appear by 7–8 months of age.
This reflex disappears by 18 months of postnatal period.

questions.solution:
The reflex being elicited in the given scenario is the parachute reflex, and this reflex remains throughout life.

The parachute reflex can be evoked by holding the infant's trunk and then suddenly lowering it as if it were falling. This will cause the infant's arms to extend in order to break the fall. Thus, it is a prerequisite for walking. The onset of this reflex is at 7-8 months of age; it fully develops by 10-11 months and persists for life. 

The parachute reflex is a primitive reflex. Primitive reflexes appear and disappear at specific times during a child's development. Any persistence or absence of these reflexes is significant for central nervous system dysfunction.

Related Pearl: Timeline for primitive reflexes

 
Reflex
Onset
Fully developed 
Duration
Palmar grasp
28 weeks of gestation
32 weeks of gestation
2-3 months postnatal
Rooting
32 weeks of gestation
36 weeks of gestation
Less prominent after 1 month postnatal
Moro
28-32 weeks of gestation
37 weeks of gestation
5-6 months postnatal
Tonic neck
35 weeks of gestation
1 month postnatal
3-4 months postnatal
Parachute
7-8 months postnatal
10-11 months postnatal
Remains throughout life

 

According to Ghai Essential Paediatrics, 9th edition, tonic neck reflex disappears by 4 months of age. According to Nelson Paediatrics, 21st edition, tonic neck reflex disappears by 6 months of age. Hence, the answer depends on the reference chosen by the examiner.

questions.text:
A drug is instilled into the right eye of the rabbit, and the left eye is used as the control. The findings obtained after some time are shown in the table and image given below.
Reflex Right eye Left eye
Corneal reflex Present Present
Light reflex Absent Present

Which of the following drugs is likely to have been instilled?
questions.solution:
On instillation of the drug, there is mydriasis in the eye and loss of light reflex. The drug is likely to be atropine. It is an anticholinergic agent. It causes mydriasis, cycloplegia, loss of light reflex, and impaired accommodation.

Autonomic supply of the eye:

The radial muscle of the iris is controlled by α1 adrenergic receptor. Stimulation of this receptor causes mydriasis. 

The sphincter muscle of the iris is controlled by the M3 and M2 cholinergic receptors. Stimulation of these receptors causes miosis.

The ciliary muscle is supplied by the β2 adrenergic receptors as well as M3 and M2 cholinergic receptors. The β2 receptors cause relaxation of the ciliary muscle, which helps in far vision, while M3 and M2 receptors cause contraction of the ciliary muscle, which helps in near vision.

Lacrimal glands are supplied by the α receptors and M3 and M2 receptors. They increase lacrimal secretion.

Effects of various drugs on the eye

Class Muscarinic receptor antagonist Cholinesterase inhibitors Muscarinic receptor agonist Adrenergic agonist Local anesthetic
Drugs Atropine, homatropine, Scopalamine, Tropicamide Physostigmine, neostigmine, pyridostigmine, organophosphorus compounds, etc Pilocarpine Epinephrine Cocaine
Mechanism of action in the eye Blocks M3 and M2 receptors Stimulates M3 and M2 receptors Stimulates M3 and M2 receptors in the eye Stimulates α1 receptor  in the eye Blocks sodium channel and blocks norepinephrine transporter
Effect on iris Mydriasis Miosis Miosis Mydriasis Mydriasis
Corneal reflex Present Present Present Present Absent
Light reflex Absent Present Present Present Present
Lacrimal secretions Decreased Increased Increased  Increased ---

Related Pearl: Effect of ANS in the Eye

  Adrenergic System Cholinergic system
  Action Receptor Action Receptor
Iris radial muscle Contraction - Mydriasis α1 --------- ---------
Iris circular muscle --------- --------- Contraction - Miosis  M3
Ciliary Muscle Relaxation – Far vision β2 Contraction – Near vision M3
Lacrimal glands Secretion + α Secretion + M3, M2

questions.text: A 50-year-old lady presented with low mood, loss of appetite, and sleep disturbances that began a month ago. She has been in good health and has no significant past or psychiatric history. Two months ago, her son was diagnosed with Hodgkin's lymphoma. She is able to carry out her daily activities and still cherishes time with her son. Which among the following is true about the prognosis of this condition?

choices.text: Most patients do not return to their previous level of functioning
Adults are more likely to improve sooner than adolescents
Suicidal risk is not a concern in these patients
Pharmacotherapy is preferred over psychotherapy for this condition.

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario with low mood, loss of appetite, and sleep disturbances occurring within 3 months of a stressful event (Son's lymphoma diagnosis) is suggestive of an adjustment disorder. Adults recover sooner than adolescents.

Adjustment disorder is an emotional response to a stressful event such as the loss of a job, divorce, moving to a new environment, financial problems, medical illnesses, or the death of a loved one. 

With appropriate treatment, the prognosis of an adjust­ment disorder is good. Most patients are able to return to their previous level of functioning within 3 months. Adolescents usually require a longer time to recover than adults and may develop mood disorders or substance­ related disorders in the future.

The suicidal risk is found to be higher in patients with chronic adjustment disorder with depressive symptoms, associated substance-related disorders in those with previous suicide attempts. The highest risk is seen in adolescent patients.

Diagnosing criteria for adjustment disorder include:

  • Development of emotional or behavioral response within 3 months of the onset of the stressor.
  • The symptoms or behavior are clinically significant, where, any one of the following are met:
    • The response is out of proportion to the severity or intensity of the stressor.
    • Significant impairment in social, occupational, or other areas of functioning.
  • Stress-related disturbance does not meet the criteria for another mental disorder or exacerbation of pre-existing mental disorder.
  • The symptoms do not represent normal bereavement.
  • Once the stressor is terminated, the symptoms do not persist for more than 6 additional months.

The mainstay of treatment is psychotherapy. Pharmacotherapy is not commonly used, however it is reasonable to use medications for specific symptoms for a brief period of time.

Related Pearl: Timeline in psychiatry

Condition Duration
Manic episode At least 1 week
Hypomania At least 4 consecutive days
Major depressive disorder

Lasts 6 to12 months with episodes for 2 or more weeks
Cyclothymia At least 2 years
Dysthymia At least 2 years
Maternal blues Starts 2–3 days after delivery and usually resolves within 10 days
Postpartum mood disturbances Onset within 4 weeks of delivery
Brief psychotic disorder Lasts < 1 month, usually stress-related
Schizophreniform disorder Lasts 1-6 months
Schizophrenia Lasts > 6 months
Schizoaffective disorder Lasts > 2 weeks
Delusional disorder Lasts > 1 month
Panic disorder An episode followed by 1 month of concern of additional attacks 
Specific phobia Lasts > 6 months
Generalized anxiety disorder Lasts > 6 months 
Acute stress disorder Lasts between 3 days and 1 month 
PTSD Lasts > 1 month 
Adjustment disorder

Symptoms occur within 3 months of the stressor and last < 6 months

May last > 6 months in presence of chronic stressor
Bulimia nervosa At least 3 months
Somatic symptom disorder Lasts > 6 months
Separation anxiety disorder Common onset at 7–9 years 
Tourette syndrome

Onset < age 18 years

Tics that persist for > 1 year 
ADHD Symptoms for > 6 months

questions.text: Which of the following is not a function of cholecystokinin?

choices.text: Relaxation of the sphincter of Oddi

questions.solution:
Cholecystokinin(CCK) inhibits gastric emptying, it does not stimulate it.

CCK is secreted by I cells in the mucosa of the upper small intestine. It is also found in nerves in the distal ileum and colon, and neurons in the cerebral cortex. Its functions include:

  • Stimulation of pancreatic enzyme secretion (option A)
  • Gallbladder contraction
  • Relaxation of the sphincter of Oddi to allow the flow of bile and pancreatic juice into the intestinal lumen (option D)
  • Inhibits gastric emptying
  • Increases the synthesis of enterokinase
  • Enhances the motility of the small intestine and colon (option C)
  • Increases the action of secretin, alkalizing the pancreatic juice
  • Trophic effect on the pancreas

The secretion of CCK is increased by:

  • Products of digestion like peptides and amino acids coming in contact with the intestinal mucosa
  • Presence of fatty acids containing >10 C atoms in the duodenum
  • CCK-releasing peptide and monitor peptide

Bile and pancreatic juice enter the duodenum in response to CCK, enhancing the digestion of protein and fat. The products of this digestion stimulate further CCK secretion, as positive feedback. However, this positive feedback is terminated when the products of digestion move further down the GI tract.

Related Pearl: Source and actions of gastrointestinal hormones

Action

Gastrin

CCK

Secretin

GIP

Motilin

Source

G cells in the stomach (antrum)

I cells of duodenum and jejunum

S cells deep in the mucosa of upper small intestine

K cells in mucosa of duodenum and jejunum

Mo cells of the duodenum and jejunum

Acid secretion

 S   I I  

Gastric emptying

   I      

Pancreatic HCO3-

   S S    

Pancreatic enzymes

   S      

Insulin release

        S  

Gall bladder contraction

   S      

Biliary 

HCO3-

      S    

Gastric motility

         S

Intestinal motility

         S

Mucosal growth

 S        

Exocrine pancreas growth

   S S    

KEY

S→Stimulates

I→ Inhibits

 

Related Pearl: Factors regulating gastric emptying

Factors that Increase gastric emptying

Factors that Decrease gastric emptying

Distension of the stomach

Distension of the duodenum

Food rich in carbohydrate

Food rich in fats > proteins

Stimulation of parasympathetic nervous system

Stimulation of sympathetic nervous system

 

Presence of fat in duodenum

 

High acidity (low pH) of the duodenal chyme

Isotonic chyme

Hypertonic >>hypotonic duodenal content

 

Breakdown products of protein digestion in the duodenum

 

Presence of any irritation in the duodenal mucosa

Gastrin

CCK, Secretin, GIP

Related Pearl: Stimuli for gastric secretion

Stimuli

Mechanism

Applied aspects

Vagal stimulation

Direct pathway

Vagus nerve innervates parietal cells and stimulates H+ secretion directly.

The neurotransmitter at these synapses is Ach, the receptor on the parietal cells is muscarinic (M3)

The second messengers for CCK are IP3 and increased intracellular [Ca2+].

Atropine, a cholinergic muscarinic antagonist, inhibits H+ secretion by blocking the direct pathway, which uses ACh as a neurotransmitter. However, it does not block H+ secretion completely because it does not inhibit the indirect pathway, which uses GRP as a neurotransmitter

Indirect pathway

Vagus nerve innervates G cells and stimulates gastrin secretion, which then stimulates H+ secretion.

The neurotransmitter at these synapses is GRP (not ACh).

Vagotomy eliminates both direct and indirect pathways.

Gastrin

Released in response to eating a meal (small peptides, distension of the stomach, vagal stimulation).

Stimulates H+ secretion by interacting with the cholecystokinin B (CCKB) receptor on the parietal cells.

The second messenger for gastrin on the parietal cell is IP3/Ca2+.

  

Histamine

Released from enterochromaffin-like (ECL) cells in the gastric mucosa and diffuses to the nearby parietal cells.

Stimulates H+ secretion by activating H2 receptors on the parietal cell membrane.

The H2 receptor is coupled to adenylyl cyclase via a Gs protein.

The second messenger for histamine is cAMP.

H2 receptor–blocking drugs, such as cimetidine, inhibit H+ secretion by blocking the stimulatory effect of histamine.

questions.text: Identify the characteristic radiographic finding shown in the image
questions.solution:
The image shows the drooping lily sign on the right side, a urographic sign observed in patients with a duplicated collecting system. 

The drooping lily sign refers to the inferolateral displacement of the opacified lower pole moiety due to an obstructed upper pole moiety.

 

Other options: 

Option A - Fish hook ureter: 

  • Bilateral Fishhook ureters ("J-shaped ureters" or "hockey stick ureter") describe the course of the distal ureter in patients with significant benign prostatic hypertrophy.
  • Right-sided fish hook ureter describes the appearance of the retrocaval ureter as the right ureter hooks behind the IVC, it has also been referred to as an S-shaped ureter.

The image given below shows right-sided fish hook ureter

 

Option C - Bouquet of flowers appearance: It is a characteristic IVP finding in the medullary sponge kidney. The ectatic distal collecting ducts contain the microcalcification giving this appearance. It is also known as the bunch of grapes appearance.

The following image shows the bouquet of flowers appearance:

 

Option D - In vesicoureteric reflex, there is an abnormal flow of urine from the bladder into the upper urinary tract. It is seen in children. It is graded as the following: 

Grade 1: reflux limited to the ureter

Grade 2: reflux into the renal pelvis

Grade 3: mild dilation of ureter and pelvicalyceal system

Grade 4: tortuous ureter with moderate dilatation, blunting of fornices with preserved papillary impressions

Grade 5: tortuous ureter with severe dilatation of the ureter and pelvicalyceal system, loss of fornices and papillary impressions

The following image shows unilateral vesicoureteric reflex.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient who underwent radiotherapy for Hodgkin's lymphoma 5 years ago presents with a slow-growing thyroid swelling for 6 months. Physical examination reveals 2 by 2cm swelling over the thyroid gland. Laboratory investigations show a normal TSH, T3, and T4. Which of the following is false regarding the underlying disease?

choices.text: The most common type of  thyroid tumor

questions.solution:
This patient with thyroid swelling, who was treated for Hodgkin’s lymphoma by radiotherapy, is likely to have papillary thyroid cancer. Papillary thyroid cancer spreads through the lymphatic system.

Radiation is the established risk factor for the development of differentiated thyroid carcinoma (papillary and follicular). This association is stronger for papillary than for follicular carcinomas.

Papillary thyroid carcinomas are the most common forms of thyroid carcinoma and present in younger individuals. They commonly spread by the lymphatic system but have an excellent 10-year survival rate of 95%.

The risk of developing papillary thyroid cancer is high among individuals who:

  • Received external irradiation to the thyroid as children (< 5 years of age)
  • Received radiation for soft tissue malignancies, such as Hodgkin’s lymphoma
  • Have a history of acute environmental exposure
  • Familial syndromes (Cowden syndrome, Werner syndrome, Carney syndrome, etc)

Clinical features -

  • thyroid swelling
  • lateral aberrant thyroid -cervical node invasion my metastasis)
  • dysphagia
  • horseness

Diagnosis -

  • Thyroid function studies
  • Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) suppression test
  • Thyroid ultrasound
  • Fine-needle aspiration biopsy (FNAB)(to confirm the diagnosis)

Histopathology -

  • Complex, branching, randomly oriented papillae with fibrovascular cores associated with follicles.
  • Usually dense fibrosis.
  • Papillae lined by cuboidal cells.
  • Nuclei are overlapping with finely dispersed optically clear chromatin (also called ground-glass), which gives a clear or empty appearance, therefore, the name is ground glass or Orphan Annie eye nuclei.
  • Macronucleoli, eosinophilic intranuclear inclusions (represent cytoplasmic invaginations) and nuclear longitudinal grooves (represent folding of the redundant nuclear membrane, but nonspecific).
  • Stromal elastosis - often lymphatic invasion.
  • Psammoma bodies.

Staging - 

  • AGES scoring system- Age, histologic Grade, Extrathyroidal invasion, and metastases and tumor Size. Predict the risk of dying from papillary cancer.
  • MACIS scale - Postoperative modification of the AGES scale. Includes Metastases, Age at presentation (<40 or >40 years old), Completeness of original surgical resection, extrathyroidal Invasion, and Size of original lesion
  • AMES system - classifies differentiated thyroid tumors. Includes Age (men <40 years old, women <50 years old), Metastases, Extrathyroidal spread, and Size of tumors (< or >5 cm). 

 

The image below shows papillary thyroid carcinoma with characteristic orphan Annie eye nuclei:

 

The image below shows psammoma bodies in papillary thyroid cancer.

Related Pearl: Papillary thyroid carcinoma

Papillary carcinoma is the most common thyroid carcinoma. It is most common in iodine sufficient areas, children and in those exposed to ionizing radiation. 

The mean age of presentation is 3rd-4th decade and is more common in women than men (2:1). Dysphagia, dysphonia and dyspnea are associated with local invasion.

It usually presents as a cold nodule on the scan. Histological findings include:

  • Branching papillae 
  • Follicles with the fibrovascular stalk
  • Psammoma bodies
  • Nuclear changes- 
    • Optically clear - Ground glass or Orphan Annie eye nuclei
    • Pseudo-inclusions
    • Nuclear grooves.

Lymph node metastasis is common. Lateral aberrant thyroid denotes a cervical lymph node invaded by papillary carcinoma. The most common sites of metastasis : lung > liver > bone > brain.

It has an excellent prognosis, with a 10-year survival rate in excess of 95%.

Related Pearl: Gene alterations in thyroid cancer

Type of Thyroid Carcinoma  Mutations
Papillary Carcinoma

BRAF mutation

RET/PTC rearrangement

MET

NTRK1 fusion gene

GDNF - glial derived neurotropic factor
Follicular carcinoma  

RAS mutation

PIK3CA mutation

PTEN mutation

PAX8/PPAR1 fusion gene
Medullary carcinoma  RET mutation
Follicular adenoma  

TSH-R mutation

Gsα (GNAS) mutation

Ras mutation (<20% cases)

PAX8/PPARγ1 fusion (<10% cases)

PTEN
 Anaplastic carcinoma  

CTNNB1 (β-catenin)

TP53 inactivation

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with lower abdominal pain, increased frequency of micturition, and pain during sex that extends to the vulva and vagina. The pain increases when the bladder is full. Cystoscopy shows fissures and punctate hemorrhages in the bladder mucosa as shown in the image below and marked submucosal edema of the bladder. Biopsy reveals mucosal ulceration and increased numbers of mucosal mast cells. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are characteristic of interstitial cystitis or chronic pelvic pain syndrome.

Interstitial cystitis is a rare idiopathic condition that occurs most frequently in women presenting as intermittent severe suprapubic pain, urinary frequency, urgency, hematuria, and dysuria. Hunner ulcers are characteristic ulcers seen in interstitial cystitis. It is characterized by marked submucosal edema of the bladder with mucosal ulceration, seen in the late phase of interstitial cystitis.

Cystoscopic findings show fissures and punctate hemorrhages (glomerulations) in the bladder mucosa. Microscopically, mucosal ulceration is covered by fibrin, necrotic material, and increased numbers of mucosal mast cells. The pathologic findings are nonspecific, and the main role of biopsy is to rule out carcinoma in situ, which may mimic interstitial cystitis clinically. Late in the course, transmural fibrosis may appear, leading to a contracted bladder.

Other options:

Option A: Malakoplakia is an inflammatory reaction caused by defects in phagocyte function. It occurs during chronic bacterial infections. On cystoscopy, it appears as soft, yellow, raised mucosal plaques 3-4cm in diameter with large aggregates of foamy macrophages.

Option B: Transitional cell carcinoma of the bladder or urothelial neoplasms are the most common bladder tumors. Morphological variants include papillary, nodular, or flat lesions. 

Option C: Follicular cystitis is characterized by multiple lymphoid follicles in the bladder mucosa or underlying wall. 

Related Pearl: Types of Cystitis

Type of cystitis Etiology Characteristic features
Interstitial cystitis Idiopathic Hunner's ulcer
Polypoid cystitis Catheterization of bladder Mimics malignancy
Malakoplakia Defective phagocytosis Michaelis– Gutmann bodies
Eosinophilic cystitis Systemic allergic disorders Submucosal eosinophils
Emphysematous cystitis Clostridium perfringens Associated with Diabetes
Follicular cystitis Prolonged urinary retention, intravesicular chemotherapy or BCG Lymphoid follicles within bladder mucosa
Hemorrhagic cystitis

Cyclo-phosphamide, BK virus, Adenovirus

 Prophylactic administration of mesna reduces the incidence
